Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Oliceridine vs. Morphine for Postoperative GI Tolerability

Trial_Design.evidence: Conducted as two randomised, double-blind, placebo- and morphine-controlled phase 3 trials

Participants.evidence: patients aged 18-75 years with Apfel scores ≥3

Intervention.evidence: randomised to receive oliceridine (0.1, 0.35, 0.5 mg) or morphine (1 mg)

Objective.evidence: This study assesses the gastrointestinal (GI) tolerability of oliceridine, a G-protein selective µ-opioid receptor agonist, compared to morphine

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was "complete GI response," defined as no vomiting and no use of rescue antiemetics, measured over 48 hours for bunionectomy and 24 hours for abdominoplasty

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, with allocation concealed using sealed envelopes

Blinding.evidence: Patients, clinicians, and outcome assessors were blinded

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 756 patients were randomised: 378 to oliceridine and 378 to morphine, between January 2018 and December 2019

Result_Outcome.evidence: Adjusted analysis showed odds ratios of 3.14 (95% CI: 1.78, 5.56; p < 0.0001) for bunionectomy and 1.92 (95% CI: 1.09, 3.36; p = 0.024) for abdominoplasty

Harms.evidence: No severe adverse events were reported, with mild GI side-effects in 3% of the oliceridine group and 1% of the morphine group
